title: 108_hr3016
content: The "Combating Terrorism Financing Act of 2003" increases penalties for terrorism financing under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act. Penalties are raised to $50,000 and twenty years for violations related to money laundering. Amendments to RICO and Section 1956(c)(7) of title 18, United States Code include inserting new sections related to illegal money transmitters, unlawful employment of aliens, and financing of terrorism. Additionally, violations of the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act and Social Security Act are addressed. Amendments to Section 1956(e) of title 18, United States Code allow for investigations by various components of the Department of Justice, Department of the Treasury, Department of Homeland Security, and the United States Postal Service in accordance with specific agreements. Amendments to Section 1957(e) of title 18, United States Code allow for investigations by the Department of Justice, Department of the Treasury, and Department of Homeland Security, as appropriate. The Secretary of Homeland Security, the Secretary of the Treasury, and the Postal Service have authority over offenses within their respective jurisdictions, as outlined in an agreement with the Attorney General. SEC. 4. ASSETS OF PERSONS COMMITTING TERRORIST ACTS AGAINST FOREIGN COUNTRIES OR INTERNATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS. Section 981(a)(1)(G) of title 18, United States Code is amended to include forfeiture of property belonging to individuals, entities, or organizations involved in planning or carrying out acts of international terrorism against international organizations or foreign governments located outside the US. The amendment to Section 981(a)(1)(G) of title 18, United States Code allows for forfeiture of property related to acts of international terrorism outside the US if planning or perpetration occurred within US jurisdiction. SEC. 5. MONEY LAUNDERING THROUGH HAWALAS. Amends Section 1956 of title 18, United States Code to include definitions of transactions involving proceeds of unlawful activity. SEC. 6. CLASSIFIED INFORMATION IN MONEY LAUNDERING PROCEEDINGS. SEC. 6. Classified Information in Money Laundering Proceedings. Amends Section 5318A of title 31, US Code to allow submission of classified information ex parte and in camera in judicial review of money laundering concerns. Technical corrections are made to various sections of title 31 and title 18 of the United States Code, including amendments to sections related to luggage, mail, and foreign banks. Amendments are made to Chapter 46 of title 18, United States Code, to include provisions for contesting the confiscation of property belonging to suspected international terrorists. Owners can contest confiscation by filing a claim and asserting that the property is not subject to confiscation or that innocent owner provisions apply. The innocent owner provisions of section 983(d) apply to the case, allowing for the admission of otherwise inadmissible evidence if it is reliable and compliance with Federal Rules of Evidence may jeopardize national security interests. The exclusion of certain provisions of Federal law from the definition of 'civil forfeiture statute' does not deny property owners the right to contest asset confiscation of suspected international terrorists under this section or the Constitution. The section excludes certain provisions of Federal law from the definition of 'civil forfeiture statute' and does not limit other available remedies for property owners under section 983 or any other law. SEC. 8. TECHNICAL CORRECTIONS TO FINANCING OF TERRORISM STATUTE. Repeals sections of Public Law 107-56 and makes amendments to title 18, United States Code regarding conspiracies and attempts in terrorism-related offenses. Section 2339C of title 18, United States Code is amended to include provisions regarding the support or resources to be provided, or knowing that they were provided or collected. Amendments also include technical corrections to the financing of terrorism statute. The term 'material support or resources' is defined in section 2339A(b) of title 18, United States Code. Section 2332b(g)(5)(B) is amended to include reference to section 2339C relating to financing of terrorism.
